entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This document provides a plain-language overview of the governance and operational structure of New Doggerland. It is intended for external audiences such as funders, partners, advisors, and regulators. The summary outlines the intent, structure, and logic of the organization’s formal governance and operational framework.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: New Doggerland is an intentionally designed organization structured around:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Clear accountability
 • Ethical decision-making
 • Long-term institutional sustainability

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: From its inception, the organization has prioritized strong governance and operational clarity to ensure transparency, trust, and resilience as it grows.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
New Doggerland is intentionally built for early-stage fundability.
Its governance and control systems are designed to operate before reputation, scale, or organizational history exist, so that donors and funding partners do not need to rely on trust, urgency, or founder discretion.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Funders are able to observe governance operating in real time, rather than inferring governance quality from outcomes.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: As organizations scale, governance typically hardens around habits, personalities, and legacy decisions. Early-stage formation is the only period in which safety, accountability, and control can be designed without legacy friction.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Accordingly, early funders of New Doggerland are not betting on outcomes. They are validating a governance system.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: New Doggerland therefore represents an opportunity to support an organization after controls are in place but before history hardens.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This framing is reflected in concrete controls already in operation, including predefined approval thresholds, aggregation limits, emergency authority constraints, segregation of duties, and explicit donor-fund protections. These controls are active by default and operate independently of urgency, outcomes, or individual discretion.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Clear rules enable creativity, fairness, and mission focus.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Rather than relying on informal norms or personality-driven leadership, the organization uses documented governance frameworks to:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Define authority and responsibility
 • Reduce ambiguity and internal conflict
 • Protect the mission over time
 • Enable leadership transitions without disruption

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: The organization maintains a tiered document hierarchy that establishes clear authority and precedence.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Authority within the organization is governed by the following order of precedence:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Applicable laws and regulations
 • Foundational governance documents
 • Operational manuals
 • Policies, procedures, and guidelines

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: In the event of a conflict, higher-level documents take precedence over lower-level ones.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: The organization maintains four primary categories of documents:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Defines mission, values, authority, and oversight
 • Establishes leadership roles and decision-making processes
 • Serves as the organization’s constitutional backbone

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Provides interpretation and practical guidance
 • Explains how governance principles are applied in practice
 • Non-binding, but highly informative

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Defines day-to-day operational authority and processes
 • Clarifies roles, workflows, and accountability
 • Ensures continuity and consistency

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Offers implementation examples and evolving best practices
 • Designed to adapt as the organization learns and grows

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This separation ensures that core principles remain stable while practices can evolve responsibly.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Clearly distinguish between oversight and execution
 • Ensure decisions are made at the appropriate level
 • Provide documented escalation and resolution pathways

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This structure protects both leadership, by clarifying authority, and the organization, by preventing unilateral or unclear decision-making.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: All governance and operational documents are versioned and intentionally labeled (e.g., v0.6.0) to reflect:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Transparency
 • Iterative improvement
 • Learning from real-world operation

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: Formal review and revision processes are built into the system to ensure ongoing relevance and compliance.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: For funders and partners, this framework demonstrates:

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Organizational seriousness and readiness
 • Risk awareness and mitigation
 • Responsible stewardship of resources

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Proactive compliance thinking
 • Clear internal controls
 • Reduced governance and operational risk

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text:
• Clarity
 • Fairness
 • Confidence in institutional stability

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This summary is provided for informational purposes only. In the event of any inconsistency, formally adopted governance and operational documents, along with applicable laws and regulations, shall govern.

entries.label: External Summary
entries.text: This governance and operations framework is a working draft, internally consistent, but not yet actively in use. It provides a strong foundation for early-stage operations and long-term organizational scale, while remaining open to structured refinement as New Doggerland grows.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
This document explains how donor funds are constrained, monitored, and reviewable
within New Doggerland’s governance and operations framework.
It is written for Donor-Advised Fund (DAF) administrators, compliance teams, and donors
seeking high-confidence, low-surprise grant pathways.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
This document does not create authority, permissions, or obligations.
If any discrepancy exists, controlling governance and operational documents prevail.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Donor-advised funds and other fiduciary intermediaries are typically advised to prioritize organizations with established operating history, scale, and demonstrated outcomes. This guidance reflects the reality that governance and accountability systems are often developed reactively, after growth has begun.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: New Doggerland was intentionally designed in the opposite order.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Governance, control, and accountability mechanisms were established prior to scale, reputation, or external validation. This allows funders to evaluate safety and stewardship directly, rather than inferring them from success.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: As organizations mature, governance systems tend to harden around existing habits and legacy decisions. Early-stage formation is therefore the only period in which safety can be designed without exception or retrofitting.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: For this reason, early funding of New Doggerland is not a speculative commitment to outcomes. It is a bounded opportunity to observe and validate governance functioning under real but constrained operating conditions.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Early funders support operations within predefined thresholds and observe governance processes such as escalation, logging, and board engagement as they occur.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Early funders do not underwrite rapid expansion, discretionary growth, or outcome-driven urgency. Their role is to validate that governance systems operate as designed before scale introduces additional complexity.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
New Doggerland is structured so that no individual can unilaterally control donor funds,
including founders, staff, or emergency actors.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Explicit Material Action thresholds requiring Governing Body approval for spending, contracts, compensation, and access.
 • Aggregation rules preventing incremental bypass of approval thresholds.
 • Segregation of duties prohibiting the same person from initiating and approving financial actions.
 • Emergency authority that is explicitly barred from affecting donor funds, contracts, or compensation.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
Any financial action must be authorized at the appropriate level, logged at the time of action,
and subject to post-action review.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Subject to donor restriction and approval level, funds may be used for:

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Direct animal welfare operations and care
 • Safety and infrastructure improvements
 • Emergency veterinary response (non-compensatory)
 • Governance, audit, and compliance capacity

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Founder or staff compensation without explicit approval
 • Expansion beyond operational capacity
 • Contracts or obligations created under emergency authority
 • Informal, undocumented, or retrospective actions
 • Any purpose outside New Doggerland’s mission lock

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: All uses are evaluated against welfare, dignity, and long-horizon stewardship constraints.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: ## Emergency situations do not bypass accountability

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: New Doggerland is designed to operate safely under stress.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Emergency authority is narrowly scoped, time-limited, and logged.
 • Emergency actions do not establish precedent.
 • Repeated or extended emergency use automatically triggers review.
 • Emergency authority cannot access or move donor funds.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: Emergencies are treated as reviewable events, not justifications for discretion.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: All material actions are subject to a tamper-evident, append-only logging system:

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Logs are created at the time of action or immediately upon stabilization.
 • Corrections occur by addition, never deletion.
 • Access and edits are traceable.
 • Gaps or delays automatically trigger review.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: This structure supports internal audit, external audit, donor inquiry, and regulator inquiry.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• The Founder holds no unilateral authority over funds or policy.
 • The Founder cannot self-authorize compensation or benefit.
 • Governance continues independently of any one individual.
 • Conflicts of interest are screened and documented.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: The system is designed to outlive personalities and remain legible to external reviewers.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: DAF safety includes the ability to pause, redirect, or unwind.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Suspension of activities that exceed capacity
 • Corrective action following logged failure
 • Donor-restricted fund accounting
 • Clean project wind-down if required

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
Most organizations rely on trust.
New Doggerland is designed for scrutiny.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text:
• Constraints are explicit.
 • Authority is bounded.
 • Failures are legible.
 • Emergencies do not expand power.
 • Oversight is structurally invited.

entries.label: DAF Safety & Accountability
entries.text: This makes New Doggerland a suitable recipient for restricted, high-accountability donor funds.

entries.text:
This appendix provides a menu of common grant pathways that align with
New Doggerland’s governance, operational constraints, and audit framework.

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text: It is intended to help Donor-Advised Funds and donors:

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• translate donor intent into enforceable restrictions,
 • select low-risk funding pathways, and
 • understand the oversight and reporting associated with each grant type.

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
This appendix does not create permissions or authority.
All grants remain subject to governing thresholds, approval requirements, and logging rules.

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Intended use

 • Oversight and review characteristics

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix

entries.text: ### 1. Animal Welfare Operations (Non-Expansionary)

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text: ### 3. Safety, Maintenance, and Infrastructure Integrity

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Facility safety upgrades
 • Repairs necessary to preserve welfare, dignity, or environmental safety
 • Replacement of degraded or hazardous equipment

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Capacity expansion or new-site development
 • Speculative or aesthetic improvements

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Subject to spending and aggregation thresholds
 • Requires documented maintenance or safety rationale
 • Reviewable through asset and infrastructure logs

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

 • Governance tooling and compliance systems
 • Training related to oversight, safety, or ethical operations

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

 • Unreviewed consulting arrangements

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:

 • Particularly suitable for risk-averse donors

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text: ### 5. Restricted Pilot or Time-Bound Program Support

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Clearly defined, time-limited initiatives
 • Programs with explicit scope, duration, and success criteria

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Open-ended commitments
 • Policy exceptions or governance overrides

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• Requires pre-defined scope and expiration
 • Subject to heightened review if extended or repeated
 • Failure or discontinuation is logged and reviewable

entries.label: Grant Menu Appendix
entries.text:
• All grant categories remain subject to New Doggerland’s mission lock,
 welfare and dignity constraints, and materiality thresholds.
 • Donor-restricted accounting and reporting are supported.
 • Clean suspension, redirection, or wind-down is possible if required.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
New Doggerland exists solely to advance its stated charitable, welfare, and stewardship purposes. Assets, authority, and operations must not deviate from these purposes. No activity may undermine dog welfare, human dignity, or the long-term stewardship obligations of the organization. 
No activity may be treated as undermining welfare, dignity, or stewardship solely because it imposes incidental, time-limited, or mitigated burdens that are necessary to prevent greater harm or to carry out mission-aligned duties under this document, provided the necessity basis is documented contemporaneously in the applicable log, interpretation note, or Recorded Decision Pathway.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: New Doggerland must designate a primary beneficiary for every operational, spatial, or experiential domain.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Within a domain, New Doggerland may optimize conditions only for the designated primary beneficiary.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Within a domain, New Doggerland must respect all non-primary beneficiaries.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: New Doggerland must not optimize conditions for more than one beneficiary within the same domain.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: New Doggerland must not use indulgence as a design, operational, or experiential objective in any domain.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• Legal and Regulatory Compliance Instruments
• This Consolidated Governance Document
• Operational Manuals
• Policies and Procedures

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: In any conflict, higher-order documents control. Legal and regulatory requirements control in all cases, regardless of any internal provision.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Subordination within this hierarchy governs authority, not interpretation. Where no direct conflict exists, good-faith interpretation at the lowest competent level is permitted only for actions that are not Material Actions, provided such interpretation does not create new authority or obligations and is recorded as an interpretation note when it affects procedure.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Interpretation notes are non-binding and do not create precedent, authority, or obligations. Interpretation notes must not be cited as independent authority in any Recorded Decision Pathway and must not be treated as policy unless formally adopted through the applicable governance or policy process.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Ambiguity alone does not constitute conflict. Only direct inconsistency between provisions triggers hierarchical override.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: All authority within New Doggerland originates exclusively from the governing hierarchy defined in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: All materials that are not part of that hierarchy, including but not limited to companion documents, public descriptions, staff handbooks, training materials, summaries, slogans, heuristics, cultural artifacts, and informal guidance, are subordinate and may exist only as derived representations of higher-order documents.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Derived materials may summarize, simplify, restate, or compress existing rules and obligations, but must not originate new authority, create new obligations, grant permissions, change thresholds, modify safeguards, or override higher-order text.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Derived materials must not be relied upon to determine rights, duties, permissions, prohibitions, or enforcement outcomes.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If any conflict, ambiguity, or inconsistency exists between a higher-order document and a derived material, the higher-order document governs without exception.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: No cultural, informal, or symbolic expression has independent authority or interpretive weight.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: External assurance documents (including donor, regulator, or auditor summaries) are derived representations and confer no authority.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Founder is a defined organizational role responsible for originating and stewarding the foundational structure, mission articulation, and long-horizon coherence of New Doggerland.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The initial Founder is the natural person who established New Doggerland and is identified as such in the organization’s formation records.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• is singular and may be occupied by only one person at a time
• does not constitute an office, officer position, ownership interest, or governance seat
• confers no voting power, veto power, or unilateral authority
• holds the non-voting Governing Body Chair role by default unless declined in writing
• may be vacated, retired from, or reassigned only in accordance with this document

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Upon retirement or voluntary transition from active stewardship, the incumbent Founder enters the Founder Steward role as defined in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Upon incapacity, entry into the Founder Steward role is permitted only if the Governing Body records a finding that the incumbent Founder can reliably perform the Chair and advisory functions described in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• does not terminate the Founder’s identity or historical status
• represents a retreat from day-to-day operational and physical work
• preserves continuity of mission articulation and long-horizon coherence

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Stewardship is an independent oversight function responsible solely for continuity, integrity, and failure backstopping where governance mechanisms cannot operate as designed.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• is not a Governing Body
• holds no policy-making, voting, or directive authority
• exists only to preserve procedural continuity and prevent deadlock or capture
• must not be occupied by any person currently serving on the Governing Body
• must not be occupied by the Founder, Founder Steward, or any executive staff

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Stewardship authority is limited strictly to the functions explicitly enumerated in this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Steward’s Office is the minimal administrative expression of Stewardship required to execute continuity functions explicitly granted by this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• may act only where this document explicitly authorizes Stewardship intervention
• must act mechanically and without discretion
• must document all actions taken
• must dissolve automatically once the triggering condition is resolved

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• issue policy
• influence governance decisions
• override votes
• persist beyond its authorized scope

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For avoidance of doubt, the requirement that the Steward’s Office act mechanically and without discretion prohibits independent judgment, prioritization, or policy interpretation. This does not prohibit the minimal application of Bounded Discretion solely where explicitly required to execute a continuity function already authorized by this document, provided that such discretion is fully documented and remains strictly constrained to execution mechanics.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Steward is appointed by Supermajority vote of the Governing Body (as defined in Section~).

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
The Steward must satisfy all eligibility requirements for Stewardship defined in Section~. Failure to meet any eligibility condition renders the appointment invalid.
If an appointment is invalid under this subsection, any person may file an Eligibility Challenge Notice. Upon receipt, the Governing Body must (1) log the notice within twenty-four (24) hours, (2) determine eligibility within fourteen (14) days, and (3) record the determination and vote result. If ineligibility is confirmed, the Stewardship role is deemed vacant as of the determination timestamp, and any actions taken under Steward authority during the ineligible period must be reviewed under the Recorded Decision Pathway within thirty (30) days.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Steward serves a fixed term of thirty-six (36) months. The Steward may be reappointed for one additional consecutive term by Supermajority vote.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Steward may be removed for cause by Supermajority vote, subject to the same procedural safeguards applicable to Governing Body member removal under this document, including documented cause and a vote record.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• failure or refusal to execute an explicitly authorized backstop function
• action outside the scope of Stewardship authority
• Credible Impairment (as defined in Section~) preventing reliable service
• concealment of a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~)

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If the Stewardship role is vacant at the time a backstop function is triggered:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the Governing Body must appoint an interim Steward within fourteen (14) days by Supermajority vote,
• until such appointment, the backstop function is held in abeyance unless immediate action is required to prevent irreversible harm, in which case a majority of the Governing Body may designate a qualified person to execute only the specific triggered function, subject to full logging and review.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For purposes of this subsection, "irreversible harm" means harm that cannot be materially remedied within thirty (30) days by lawful expenditure, medical intervention, or operational correction.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If the Governing Body fails to appoint an interim Steward within fourteen (14) days due solely to inability to reach Supermajority, then on day fifteen (15) the Governing Body must either (1) appoint an interim Steward by simple majority for a maximum interim term of sixty (60) days, or (2) invoke the External Governance Arbiter mechanism, with the invocation logged and the reason stated.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Upon term expiration, the Stewardship role becomes vacant unless the Steward has been reappointed before the expiration timestamp, in which case the new term begins immediately upon expiration.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Supermajority is an affirmative vote of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of all active voting seats of the Governing Body, rounded up to the next whole number where necessary.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Abstentions, absences, and vacancies do not reduce the number of votes required unless this document explicitly states otherwise.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Voluntary or precautionary recusals do not reduce the number of votes required.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Where one or more members are subject to a mandatory recusal, the Supermajority denominator is the number of non-recused active voting seats. The two-thirds (2/3) threshold, rounded up, applies to the adjusted denominator.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A recusal is mandatory when this document requires recusal due to a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~), a Related-Party Transaction (as defined in Section~), or any other provision that expressly prohibits a member's participation in discussion, influence, or vote on the matter at issue.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The adjusted denominator must constitute quorum (a majority of all active voting seats as defined in Section~). If the number of non-recused active voting seats falls below quorum, the matter must be referred to an External Governance Arbiter (as defined in Section~) for binding determination on the specific matter referred, subject to the following constraints:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the Arbiter must issue written findings applying the same substantive standards that would govern a Governing Body vote,
• the Arbiter's determination is limited to the specific matter referred and creates no precedent,
• the referral, findings, and determination must be logged as a Material Action with a Recorded Decision Pathway, and
• the Arbiter must not be selected by any recused member.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: This subsubsection constitutes an explicit grant of scope to the External Governance Arbiter for purposes of Section~ and does not expand Arbiter authority beyond the specific referred matter.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An Extraordinary Process is a modification process that requires all of the following:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An Extraordinary Process must not be completed through emergency authority, delegation, administrative action, or procedural shortcut.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Active Voting Seats are Governing Body seats that are currently filled by members whose terms are valid and not suspended or disqualified due to removal, resignation, Credible Impairment determination, classification-related suspension, or expiration of term.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Vacant seats, expired terms, and seats subject to formal suspension or disqualification do not constitute Active Voting Seats for purposes of quorum, Supermajority calculations, or voting thresholds unless this document explicitly states otherwise.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Properly Requested Meeting is a Governing Body meeting requested in accordance with all of the following conditions:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the request is made in writing
• the request specifies the matters to be addressed
• the request is delivered to the Governing Body Chair and all voting members
• the request is supported by not less than one-third (1/3) of all active voting members
• the requested meeting date is not less than seven (7) days and not more than thirty (30) days from the date of request

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure by the Governing Body Chair to convene a Properly Requested Meeting within the requested window constitutes refusal for purposes of any procedural backstop in this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A decision materially affects a person, asset, domain, or obligation if it meets one or more of the following conditions:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• creates, modifies, or terminates a right, duty, protection, or restriction
• alters safety conditions, welfare outcomes, or dignity protections
• commits, transfers, encumbers, or risks organizational assets or land
• establishes precedent that would reasonably influence future decisions of a similar type
• changes governance structure, authority allocation, or review thresholds

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A decision must be treated as materially affecting if reasonable disagreement exists as to its impact, provided that the disagreement is grounded in plausible, non-speculative effects within a reasonable operational time horizon based on facts known or reasonably available at the time. Abstract, hypothetical, or purely downstream disagreement does not, by itself, render an action materially affecting.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Material Action is any action, decision, omission, authorization, or override that materially affects (as defined in Section~) any person, asset, domain, obligation, safety condition, welfare outcome, dignity protection, or governance mechanism.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• any decision that requires a recorded vote under this document
• any invocation of emergency authority
• any override of a policy, procedure, safeguard, or default restriction
• any action that establishes precedent that would reasonably influence future decisions of a similar type
• routine actions that are reversible, role-scoped, and logged do not become Material Actions solely due to hypothetical precedent concerns or abstract downstream disagreement.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If reasonable disagreement exists, as qualified under Section~, as to whether an action is material, it must be treated as a Material Action.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Recorded Decision Pathway is the minimum complete written record that shows how and why a Material Action (as defined in Section~) was authorized and executed.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Recorded Decision Pathway must include all of the following:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• a unique identifier for the action record
• the actor or body that authorized the action
• the date and time of authorization
• the triggering conditions and the specific decision being made
• the scope of impact, including what is affected and what is not affected
• the authority basis, including the specific section(s) of this document or operational manual procedure relied upon
• any required vote record, quorum status, recusals, and abstentions where applicable
• the logging location and the person responsible for completing any follow-on documentation

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If any required element is missing, the Recorded Decision Pathway is invalid.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For emergency actions, a Recorded Decision Pathway exists upon creation of a compliant emergency log stub containing, at minimum:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the unique identifier
• the actor invoking emergency authority
• the triggering conditions
• the scope and emergency procedure invoked

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: All missing elements must be completed within the time limits required by the applicable operational manual emergency procedure.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Bounded Discretion is the minimum unavoidable judgment exercised to apply a rule whose trigger or scope cannot be executed mechanically.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the triggering standard cannot be applied using objective criteria alone,
• the actor documents the basis for the judgment contemporaneously,
• the judgment is limited to the narrowest scope consistent with preventing harm or meeting the duty, and
• the action remains fully subject to logging, review, and classification requirements under this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• expand authority beyond what is explicitly granted,
• bypass required votes, recusals, or quorum safeguards,
• create precedent beyond the specific facts documented in the record.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For purposes of this document and the Operational Manuals:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• Routine means an action that is customary for the role, low-complexity, and does not create or modify rights, restrictions, or governance allocations.
• Reversible means the action can be undone or returned to the prior baseline without requiring governance approval, without material cost, and without creating ongoing obligations or irreversible reliance.
• Role-Scoped means the action falls within a written role description, role charter, or operational delegation record that is maintained and reviewable.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An External Governance Arbiter is an independent individual or body retained solely to provide neutral adjudication, review, or approval functions expressly required by this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An External Governance Arbiter must satisfy all of the following conditions:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• is not a current or former member of the Governing Body
• is not the Founder, Founder Steward, or any executive or employee of the organization
• has no material financial, familial, or supervisory relationship with any governed party
• has not provided paid services to the organization within the preceding twenty-four (24) months, except for prior arbiter service
• has no contingent compensation tied to outcomes
• is selected through a documented process designed to preserve independence

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• holds no governing authority
• may not issue policy
• may act only within the scope explicitly granted by this document
• must issue written findings when required

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure to meet any eligibility condition renders the Arbiter appointment invalid.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Controlled Subsidiary is any legal entity in which New Doggerland directly or indirectly:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• owns more than fifty percent (50\
• has contractual power to appoint a majority of governing managers, directors, or equivalent controlling decision-makers, or
• has effective control over budget approval, profit distribution decisions, or liquidation decisions.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For avoidance of doubt, a for-profit entity may be a Controlled Subsidiary.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Subsidiary Governance Charter is a written instrument adopted by the Governing Body that defines the subsidiary’s:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• purpose and permitted activity scope,
• governance structure and appointment method,
• oversight and reporting obligations to New Doggerland,
• conflict-of-interest and related-party transaction rules,
• profit distribution and reserve policy,
• shutdown, divestment, or dissolution triggers and process.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Subsidiary Governance Charter is subordinate to this Consolidated Governance Document pursuant to Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Related-Party Transaction is any transaction, contract, lease, service agreement, loan, transfer, or in-kind arrangement between:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• New Doggerland and a Controlled Subsidiary,
• two or more Controlled Subsidiaries,
• New Doggerland or a Controlled Subsidiary and the Founder, Founder Steward, any Governing Body member, any executive staff, or any member of their households,
• New Doggerland or a Controlled Subsidiary and any entity in which any of the above persons holds a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~).

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An Independent Supervisor Layer is a bona fide supervisory role that satisfies all of the following conditions:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the supervisor is not a member of the Governing Body
• the supervisor is not the Founder or Founder Steward
• the supervisor does not report to the supervised person
• the supervisor has documented authority to evaluate performance, enforce standards, and recommend discipline or termination
• the supervisor’s compensation, role security, and evaluation are not controlled by the supervised person

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A nominal, ceremonial, or conflicted supervisory arrangement does not constitute an Independent Supervisor Layer.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Credible Impairment is a demonstrable condition that materially prevents a person from reliably performing the essential duties of their role.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A finding of Credible Impairment requires documented evidence of one or more of the following:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• persistent inability to participate meaningfully in required duties
• sustained cognitive, physical, or psychological limitation affecting judgment, reliability, or capacity
• medically documented incapacity relevant to role performance
• repeated failure to meet role obligations despite reasonable accommodation

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• disagreement, dissent, or unpopular positions
• age, disability status, or protected characteristics
• temporary illness, stress, or isolated incidents
• uncorroborated allegations or subjective impressions

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any determination of Credible Impairment must be documented, reviewable, and subject to the same procedural safeguards applicable to removal for cause.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Material Financial Interest exists when a person has any direct or indirect financial stake that could reasonably influence, or be perceived to influence, their judgment, independence, or conduct with respect to the organization.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Material Financial Interest includes, but is not limited to:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• ownership, equity, profit-sharing, or revenue participation in a vendor, contractor, partner, or counterparty
• receipt of compensation, consulting fees, retainers, commissions, or success-based payments
• outstanding loans, guarantees, or financial obligations involving the organization
• expectation of future compensation or benefit contingent on organizational action
• financial interests held by a spouse, domestic partner, or household member that would reasonably affect independence

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• size or percentage if the interest is non-trivial to the holder
• whether compensation is labeled informal, deferred, conditional, or non-cash
• whether the interest is routed through an intermediary entity

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A financial interest is not material solely because of:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• compensation received as an employee under standard employment terms
• reimbursement for documented expenses
• de minimis gifts disclosed and approved under policy

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any reasonable doubt as to materiality must be resolved in favor of classification as material.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: An Independently Valued Housing Benefit is a non-transferable, non-owning residential use right provided solely for organizational continuity, security, or operational necessity.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• must be supported by a documented business-necessity rationale
• must be independently valued at fair market rental value by a qualified, disinterested assessor
• must be reviewed periodically as required by this document
• must be disclosed internally and in donor-facing transparency materials
• must be evaluated and reported consistently with applicable tax, disclosure, and reporting requirements, including inclusion in total compensation analysis where required

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure to meet these requirements converts the benefit into a Material Financial Interest.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Independently Verifiable Compensation Data is compensation information sourced from entities or datasets that are external to the organization, methodologically transparent, and reasonably resistant to manipulation.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Independently Verifiable Compensation Data must satisfy all of the following:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• originate from a source not controlled by the organization or the compensated individual
• disclose methodology or sampling basis sufficient to assess reliability
• be current within a reasonable time horizon relative to the compensation decision
• be accessible for review, audit, or replication

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Acceptable sources include, but are not limited to:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• nationally or regionally recognized compensation surveys
• government labor statistics or public labor databases
• reputable industry compensation benchmarks
• independently conducted third-party studies

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• internally generated surveys or estimates
• anecdotal reports or recruiter representations without supporting data
• non-transparent web aggregators lacking methodological disclosure
• sources with a direct financial interest in the compensation outcome

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Where multiple credible sources diverge, the Governing Body must document the rationale for selecting the benchmark used.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any reasonable doubt as to independence or verifiability must be resolved against use of the data.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Upper End of Prevailing Market Norms means compensation at or above the seventy-fifth (75th) percentile of independently verifiable market compensation for comparable roles, responsibilities, experience, and geographic context.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• use Independently Verifiable Compensation Data (as defined in Section~)
• rely on multiple reputable sources where available
• default to the higher benchmark where credible sources diverge

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If percentile data is unavailable for a role, the Governing Body must document a conservative proxy methodology designed to approximate the seventy-fifth (75th) percentile and must disclose the limitation.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any reasonable doubt as to percentile placement must be resolved upward.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Compensation Philosophy Framework is a documented, role-tiered approach to compensation that establishes target ranges, benchmarking methods, and adjustment criteria consistent with organizational sustainability, dignity protections, and non-extractive principles.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• define role categories with comparable responsibility and risk profiles
• specify target compensation ranges for each category using independent benchmarks
• identify conditions under which compensation may be set above or below target
• preserve the Dignity Floor under all circumstances
• prohibit retaliation, coercion, or mission-based underpayment
• be documented and reviewable

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure to maintain or follow an approved Compensation Philosophy Framework constitutes a governance failure requiring remediation.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Dignity Floor is the minimum compensation level below which no participating individual may be reduced under any hardship, emergency, or continuity mechanism.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Dignity Floor must be sufficient to meet basic living needs for the applicable role holder and must be determined using objective, externally verifiable criteria.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• housing costs at modest, non-luxury levels within the relevant geographic area
• food sufficient for nutritional adequacy
• basic utilities and communications
• healthcare access or insurance continuity
• transportation necessary to perform required duties

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• publicly available cost-of-living data
• government poverty, subsistence, or living-wage benchmarks
• regional housing and expense indices

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• rely on individual frugality, sacrifice, or mission alignment
• assume unpaid labor, deferred compensation, or future make-whole promises
• be set below any legally mandated minimums

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Where multiple benchmarks exist, the highest applicable benchmark must be used unless the Governing Body documents a clear, non-extractive justification for an alternative.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Dignity Floor determination must be documented, reviewable, and disclosed to affected persons prior to any compensation reduction.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any reasonable doubt as to adequacy must be resolved in favor of the individual.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: This Mission Statement is non-binding. It exists to clarify intent and orientation. It does not grant authority, create obligations, or supersede any provision of this Consolidated Governance Document or any governing document derived from it. In the event of any conflict, this Mission Statement is subordinate to this Consolidated Governance Document and to the governing hierarchy stated in Section .

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: New Doggerland exists to restore and protect the dignity of dogs and people through long-term stewardship, direct care, and community access to safe, diverse environments for coexistence, where such access is consistent with animal welfare and dignity constraints. All New Doggerland operations exist to support and sustain animal rescue, sanctuary, and adoption, and may not operate independently of that purpose. The organization proceeds with restraint, prioritizing animal and human dignity over growth, efficiency, popularity, or scale, and accepting limits on expansion, cost, or scope when required to uphold that standard. New Doggerland advances incrementally, adding features and services only as ethical capacity and funding allow, and refusing activities or funding that would compromise its mission or shift its intentions. It is structured to endure rather than to scale, to remain accountable to the future, and to continue providing care and service even under constraint.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body holds ultimate authority over organizational decisions, subject to the constraints of this document and applicable law. No individual may exercise unilateral control over governance outcomes.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Creation, acquisition, or assumption of control of any Controlled Subsidiary (as defined in Section~) constitutes a Material Action under Section~ and requires a Recorded Decision Pathway under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: No Controlled Subsidiary may be created, acquired, or controlled unless:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the Governing Body approves the action by Supermajority vote as defined in Section~,
• a Subsidiary Governance Charter (as defined in Section~) is adopted prior to execution of any controlling instrument, and
• the Charter explicitly states the subsidiary’s permitted scope and the prohibition on the subsidiary creating new authority for New Doggerland beyond this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Subsidiary Oversight and Operational Independence

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body retains ultimate oversight responsibility for all Controlled Subsidiaries. Such oversight is limited to:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• approval of the Subsidiary Governance Charter and any amendments,
• approval of annual subsidiary budgets and capital commitments above Charter-defined thresholds,
• appointment or removal of subsidiary managers or directors only as permitted by the Charter,
• review of quarterly reports required by Section~ and Section~,
• enforcement actions and shutdown/divestment actions under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Except for the oversight functions explicitly enumerated in this subsection and in the applicable Subsidiary Governance Charter, the Governing Body must not direct day-to-day subsidiary operations.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: No subsidiary governance instrument, policy, or practice may be treated as creating authority over New Doggerland beyond the governing hierarchy in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Subsidiary Conflicts and Related-Party Transactions

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: All Related-Party Transactions (as defined in Section~) constitute Material Actions under Section~ and require a Recorded Decision Pathway under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: No Related-Party Transaction may be approved unless:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• all persons with a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~) are fully disclosed and fully recused from discussion, influence, and vote,
• the transaction is documented as fair, non-extractive, and at or better than market terms to New Doggerland or the affected subsidiary,
• the Governing Body records the basis for fairness contemporaneously in the Recorded Decision Pathway.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Subsidiary Governance Charter must include a mechanical conflict screening workflow and must prohibit informal or undocumented arrangements between New Doggerland and any Controlled Subsidiary.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Subsidiary Profit Distribution and Reserve Policy

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Each Controlled Subsidiary must operate under a documented profit distribution and reserve policy contained in its Subsidiary Governance Charter.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The default permitted direction of value transfer is from subsidiary to New Doggerland. Transfers from New Doggerland to any Controlled Subsidiary are prohibited unless:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• structured as a written, market-rate loan or documented capital contribution,
• approved as a Material Action by Supermajority vote under Section~,
• documented with a Recorded Decision Pathway under Section~,
• and demonstrated to be necessary to preserve mission-aligned continuity without creating dependency or extraction risk.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Subsidiary distributions to New Doggerland must not be represented as donor-directed unless legally restricted and recorded as such. Subsidiary profits must not be relied upon to justify reduction of any Dignity Floor obligations under Section~ or to subsidize extractive labor practices.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Subsidiary Shutdown, Divestment, or Dissolution Authority

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Shutdown, divestment, dissolution, or loss of control of any Controlled Subsidiary constitutes a Material Action under Section~ and requires a Recorded Decision Pathway under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body may authorize shutdown or divestment by Supermajority vote under Section~ if any of the following conditions are met:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the subsidiary materially undermines the Mission Lock in Section~,
• the subsidiary creates material welfare, dignity, safety, or stewardship risk as defined in Section~,
• the subsidiary requires ongoing subsidy from New Doggerland in violation of Section~,
• the subsidiary presents credible compliance risk that cannot be mitigated through narrower controls.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Subsidiary Governance Charter must include a mechanical shutdown and wind-down procedure that prioritizes legal compliance, staff dignity protections, and prevention of harm to animals and persons.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If any Controlled Subsidiary becomes operationally dominant such that reasonable risk exists of mission inversion or governance capture, the Governing Body must initiate a mandatory dominance review as a Material Action under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: For purposes of this subsection, operational dominance exists if one or more of the following conditions holds for two consecutive quarterly reporting periods:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the subsidiary accounts for a majority of consolidated gross revenue,
• the subsidiary accounts for a majority of consolidated payroll or headcount,
• the subsidiary’s contractual obligations or liabilities would materially constrain New Doggerland’s ability to comply with the Mission Lock in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• document capture risks and mission inversion risks,
• identify controls to preserve mission integrity, including but not limited to tighter Charter constraints, governance separation, reserve rules, or divestment planning,
• and be recorded as a Recorded Decision Pathway under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure to initiate or record a required dominance review constitutes a governance process failure requiring remediation under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Founder (as defined in Section~) and the Founder Steward (as defined in Section~) may issue written Strategic Articulations describing evolving structure, priorities, or implementation pathways consistent with the mission.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• carries no binding authority,
• must be formally reviewed by the Governing Body,
• must be placed on the agenda of the next regular Governing Body meeting, and
• must have its consideration recorded in the meeting record.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Governing Body Composition, Selection, and Removal

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body must consist of an odd number of voting members. The Governing Body must have no fewer than five (5) and no more than eleven (11) voting members.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any increase in the maximum number of voting seats beyond eleven (11) requires an Extraordinary Process (as defined in Section~).

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A person may serve on the Governing Body only if they can act independently and disclose conflicts.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A person may serve on the Governing Body only if they demonstrate a sustained, good-faith commitment to animal welfare, human welfare, or responsible animal stewardship, as evaluated through the organization’s formal Board vetting process.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Governing Body membership is conditional on continued compliance with this requirement. Discovery of disqualifying conduct triggers mandatory review and removal in accordance with Governing Body removal procedures.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A person must not serve on the Governing Body if they:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• are the Founder (as defined in Section~)
• are the Founder’s spouse
• are a member of the Founder’s household
• are a current employee whose role reports directly to the Governing Body without an Independent Supervisor Layer (as defined in Section~)
• have a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~) in vendors, partners, or contracts with the organization
• have ever been convicted of, or are subject to a substantiated judicial or regulatory finding for, animal cruelty, animal abuse, animal neglect, or cruelty toward humans

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body must not appoint a replacement without documenting:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the selection method used
• the candidate’s disclosed conflicts
• the reason the candidate satisfies independence requirements

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Governing Body members serve fixed terms of 24 months.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A Governing Body member must not serve more than two consecutive terms.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Terms must be staggered so that no more than a simple majority of seats expire within any 90-day period.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: No less frequently than once every five (5) years, the Governing Body must commission an independent composition review conducted by a reviewer who satisfies the eligibility requirements for an External Governance Arbiter (as defined in Section~).

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the professional, experiential, and perspective breadth of the current Governing Body,
• whether successive appointment cycles have produced material convergence in background, affiliation, or viewpoint, and
• whether the board selection process has operated in a manner consistent with the organization's long-term mission resilience.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The reviewer holds no appointment authority and may not direct or constrain Governing Body selection decisions.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The reviewer must issue written findings. The findings must be published to stakeholders.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body must record a written response before completing the next appointment cycle following the review. The response must state acceptance, partial adoption, or documented rejection with stated reasoning for each finding.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Failure to commission or complete a required composition review constitutes a governance process failure requiring remediation under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Mutability: Revisable only by Extraordinary Process

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body may remove a member for cause by Supermajority vote as defined in Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• concealment of conflicts
• repeated nonattendance that prevents quorum
• retaliation
• misuse of authority
• Credible Impairment (as defined in Section~) preventing reliable service

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body must document the cause and the vote record for any removal.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Quorum requires a majority of all Active Voting Seats.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: A decision that materially affects (as defined in Section~) welfare, safety, dignity, assets, land, or dissolution requires a recorded vote and must not be made without quorum.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If a vacancy causes loss of quorum, the Governing Body must prioritize restoring quorum before making irreversible decisions.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: ### Non-Voting Governing Body Chair (Procedural Steward Role)

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair is a procedural role that presides over Governing Body meetings and safeguards procedural integrity.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• does not constitute an office, officer position, or governance seat
• confers no voting power, veto power, or unilateral authority
• exists solely to facilitate orderly process and continuity

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Founder (as defined in Section~) occupies the non-voting Governing Body Chair role unless the Founder declines the position in writing, subject only to removal as permitted under Section~.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair must not vote on any Governing Body matter.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair does not count toward quorum unless separately appointed as a voting member.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair is not a voting member by virtue of holding the Chair role.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair holds no unilateral authority over Governing Body decisions, appointments, removals, or votes.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body may amend the meeting agenda by majority vote at any time.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: #### Chair Neutrality and Facilitation Constraints.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair must facilitate meetings in a procedurally neutral manner.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• maintain a fair speaking order and reasonable time limits
• restate motions and vote questions verbatim or by reference to written text, without persuasive framing
• apply agenda sequencing consistently unless amended by the Governing Body
• ensure all required votes, recusals, and quorum status are recorded

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• summarize or characterize debate in a manner that advocates for an outcome
• suppress agenda items properly requested under this document
• condition recognition, access to the floor, or scheduling on agreement, deference, or silence

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Any voting member may require that a Chair neutrality concern be entered into the meeting record as a procedural note.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If the Governing Body Chair fails or refuses to convene a regular meeting or a Properly Requested Meeting (as defined in Section~), a simple majority of voting members may convene the meeting without the Chair.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair must not cast tie-breaking votes.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Governing Body Chair may be removed only by the Governing Body as follows:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• Removal requires a Supermajority vote as defined in Section~.
• Removal additionally requires written confirmation by a pre-approved External Governance Arbiter (as defined in Section~) that:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the process used was procedurally fair,
• the grounds are documented and non-pretextual, and
• the removal is not retaliation for dissent, reporting, cooperation with review, or other protected conduct under this document.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• repeated failure or refusal to convene required meetings, including Properly Requested Meetings (as defined in Section~)
• repeated procedural misconduct that materially impairs governance function
• Credible Impairment (as defined in Section~) preventing reliable performance of Chair duties
• concealment of a Material Financial Interest (as defined in Section~) relevant to Chair process
• obstruction of records, agendas, minutes, vote recording, or required logging

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• the specific grounds relied upon
• the vote record
• any recusals and conflicts
• the Arbiter’s written confirmation

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: If the Chair is removed, the Governing Body must appoint an interim procedural Chair by majority vote from among non-disqualified persons who are not voting members, or may appoint a voting member solely to serve as interim procedural Chair without conferring additional authority beyond this Chair role.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: The Founder Steward is a post-operational stewardship state of the Founder role, analogous to a Founder Emeritus position.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• represents a deliberate retreat from routine physical, managerial, or operational labor
• preserves the Founder’s role as the long-horizon integrative mind of the organization
• serves as cultural, architectural, and systemic continuity anchor

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: #### Aesthetic Stewardship and Directional Authority

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: New Doggerland establishes an Aesthetic Stewardship Domain governing visual, spatial, material, atmospheric, and experiential coherence across the estate.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
The Founder Steward role holds exclusive authority to issue aesthetic compatibility determinations within the Aesthetic Stewardship Domain while the role exists.
This authority attaches to the role, not the individual.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Aesthetic compatibility determinations are non-binding unless adopted by the Governing Body through the applicable governance process.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Within the Aesthetic Stewardship Domain, the Founder Steward may determine whether proposed designs, constructions, environments, or presentations are aesthetically compatible with New Doggerland.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: This authority applies to architectural language and materials; landscape treatment and environmental form; signage visual grammar and illumination style; uniforms and public-facing appearance; soundscape and ambient sensory design; and the experiential tone of guest-accessible spaces.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Aesthetic Stewardship authority must not control budgets; must not direct operations; must not manage personnel; must not override adopted policy; must not suspend safety, accessibility, labor, zoning, or regulatory compliance; and must not create binding obligations outside the Aesthetic Stewardship Domain.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
Aesthetic Stewardship authority may not be delegated, subdivided, or exercised by committee.
No other role may claim aesthetic authority by analogy or precedent.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
If a conflict arises between Aesthetic Stewardship and safety requirements, accessibility requirements, legal or regulatory obligations, or human or animal dignity protections, the non-aesthetic requirement prevails automatically.
No justification is required.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Mutability: Revisable only by Extraordinary Process

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text: Directional authority must not prescribe methods; must not mandate timelines; must not bind budgets; must not compel operational actions; and must not override Governing Body governance or fiduciary duty.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
The Founder Steward may state that a proposal is directionally incompatible with New Doggerland.
Such a statement does not block adoption, does not invalidate the proposal, and must be recorded alongside the decision if the proposal proceeds.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document

Observable signs of life-threatening or urgent medical distress requiring immediate intervention.

entries.text:

entries.text:

Handoff to medical authority or stabilization with refusal of further care.

entries.text:

Animal in acute distress creating imminent risk to life or severe injury.

entries.label: Consolidated Governance Document
entries.text:
• Remove immediate hazard.
• Relocate animal to nearest safe containment or treatment-ready area.
• Contact pre-approved emergency veterinary resources.

entries.text:
• Experimental treatment.
• Sedation or euthanasia.

entries.text:

Animal stabilized or transferred to qualified care.

Visible smoke or flame, alarm activation with corroboration, or credible report of fire risk.

Utility or fire authority clearance.
