entries.text:
Status: Non-binding founder-origin explanatory document (derived) \\
Authority: Subordinate to ``New Doggerland -- Consolidated Governance Document v0.6.0'' and all binding schedules and operational manuals \\
Purpose: Articulate end state, design intent, motivations, and staged pathway without creating authority \\
Hierarchy: Derived representation; confers no independent authority \\
Mutability: Revisable (non-binding), subject to the Derivation and Compression Principle

entries.label: Founder Vision
Founder Vision
entries.text: If any conflict, ambiguity, or inconsistency exists between this document and the Consolidated Governance Document (or any higher-order instrument), the higher-order instrument governs without exception.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intentionally being built with a governance-first architecture. This document exists to supply what governance documents are not designed to hold:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• the intended mature end state (``what the institution becomes''),
• the motivating design origin (``why this form''),
• the conceptual logic of how the pieces relate (``how it stays coherent''),
• the staged pathway (``how it is intended to be built without overreach''),
• and the Founder-in-absentia intent (``how it remains functional without the Founder'').

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: This document is written to be legible to staff, stewards, funders, auditors, partners, and future successors, while remaining non-binding and subordinate.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ## Design Origin and Motivation (Non-binding narrative)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland's form is inspired by childhood experiences in European forest resorts designed around an uncommon kind of safety: a bounded environment with enough predictability and competence that parents could allow children meaningful freedom without constant fear. The environment offered comfort and autonomy (self-contained lodging, warmth, water, and a strong sense of ``everything is handled'') paired with clear and enforceable constraints (explicit rules, safe-approved inputs, and defaults that reduced risk and prevented misuse).

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The result was not indulgence for its own sake, but a dignity-preserving state: freedom without chaos, and rest without vigilance. The Founder intends to recreate that feeling in a contemporary, welfare-first context.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ### Freedom-by-design, not vigilance-by-monitoring

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: A core aspiration is to make it possible again for a child to say after lunch, ``I'm going to the activity area,'' and for a parent to be able to say ``okay'' without spiraling into vigilance. The intent is not to guarantee outcomes, but to design conditions that make serious harm unlikely through:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• bounded geography and controlled access points,
• clear rules and humane defaults,
• competent staffing and visible help,
• predictable procedures for reunification and escalation,
• and environments designed to reduce foreseeable hazards.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Where reassurance technologies are used (e.g., opt-in RFID wristbands), they are intended as optional supports for families who want them, not as structural prerequisites for safety or a mechanism of control. New Doggerland is intended to be safe enough that it would not rely on tracking to function safely. Any optional tracking is intended to be purpose-limited to safety and reunification, dignity-preserving, and protected against misuse.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: This same logic is intended to apply to dogs: dogs should experience agency within safety---space, enrichment, calm, and structured coexistence---without being pushed into spectacle, stress, or unmanaged exposure. The environment must remain welfare-first and dignity-bounded.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ## End State: What New Doggerland Is Intended to Become

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intended to become a dog-centered stewardship campus that is:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• welfare-first (dogs as primary beneficiaries),
• dignity-preserving (humans protected as co-beneficiaries; no coercion, retaliation, or extraction),
• stewardship-bounded (land and assets treated as long-horizon duties),
• financially resilient (able to sustain care without drifting into extraction),
• and governance-legible (major choices are explainable, logged, and reviewable).

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The intended maturity state is not maximum scale. It is a stable ethical equilibrium: a place that can operate for decades without mission drift, capture, or degradation of care standards.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: To keep scope coherent, the intended end state is organized into concentric layers:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: #### Ring 1: Mission Core (Primary, non-negotiable)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The mission core is the institution's reason for existence:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• a world-class dog sanctuary for dogs who would otherwise be euthanized or lack viable placement,
• a rescue intake and adoption center designed for high welfare and low-stress transitions,
• a veterinary clinic capable of supporting the institution's care obligations,
• a grooming and coat-care operation supporting welfare and contributing to operational sustainability.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Where implemented, additional sanctuaries (e.g., donkeys and goats) are separate welfare domains with separate safety and dignity constraints and must not compromise the dog mission.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: #### Ring 2: Dog-forward experience layer (Real, but constitutionally subordinated)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intended to include a dog-forward forest-resort form because the experience itself matters: restorative coexistence, joy, calm, and a dignified environment where families and dogs can live together safely for a time.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: This layer is not an end in isolation. It is constitutionally subordinated to the welfare mission and must not become indulgence-led, extractive, or mission-inverting. The experience layer may include:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• villas or other lodging distributed through a curated forest environment,
• a compact ``village'' core with essential guest services and education interfaces,
• curated, dog-centered forest activities designed for safe coexistence and public learning,
• all-weather facilities to reduce seasonality risk (potentially including indoor water facilities) only where consistent with welfare, dignity, stewardship, and compliance constraints.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Surplus and institutional advantage from this layer are intended to support the mission core and its public education interface rather than private benefit.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: #### Ring 3: Public-benefit perimeter (Civic access, bounded scope)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Where compatible with welfare, dignity, safety, and long-horizon stewardship, New Doggerland is intended to provide public-benefit access systems such as:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• public walking trails and nature access routes,
• dog parks and dog-forward outdoor spaces,
• limited recreation amenities (e.g., disc golf, forest golf, biking facilities) only where they remain compatible with animal welfare and do not create unmanaged risk, extraction, or mission inversion.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: #### Ring 4: Community programs (Strictly bounded, separable, safety-first)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: A bounded set of community-facing programs may exist where safety and operational separability can be preserved:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• partnerships with search-and-rescue and appropriate working-dog organizations (including police K9 units) only where training is compatible with welfare and dignity and is structured to be publicly legible and educational rather than opaque,
• temporary housing and vocational pathways for adults aging out of foster care, implemented only with clear safeguards, supervision, and non-extractive standards,
• secure temporary sanctuary lodging for survivors of domestic violence, implemented only where confidentiality and safety can be preserved without compromising the mission core.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: These programs are intended as additive public benefit, not a replacement mission, and must not compromise the dog welfare core.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ## On-site Partner Ecosystem (Small Business and Artisan ``Service Commons'')

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intended to host a bounded ecosystem of on-site partners---small businesses and artisans---whose presence directly supports operations, reduces waste, increases resilience, and strengthens local economic participation. This partner layer is not an independent objective. It exists only to support mission execution, stewardship, and institutional durability.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• food provisioning and cafés (where compatible with the site and public interface),
• repair and maintenance services (repair workshop, fabrication/metalwork),
• durable goods and uniform/boot repair or production (bootmaker/leatherworker),
• mission-supporting production (e.g., animal nutrition preparation) only where consistent with welfare constraints and regulatory compliance.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Where appropriate, partners may satisfy a portion of rent through in-kind provisioning of goods or services directly used by New Doggerland operations (e.g., bakery provisioning for on-site facilities; staff boots maintained and repaired; metal fixtures fabricated and repaired). Such arrangements are intended to be treated as priced, auditable exchanges rather than informal barter. They must not become channels for hidden compensation, private benefit, favoritism, or informal authority.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The partner ecosystem is intended to remain strictly subordinate to the mission core and must not become operationally dominant. It must not create governance capture risk, informal authority, or mission inversion. Partners exist to ``feed into the system,'' not to define the system.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ### Closed-loop infrastructure (waste-to-heat) as stewardship, conditional

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Where legally and ethically feasible, New Doggerland intends to pursue on-site processing of human and animal waste with heat recovery to reduce the energy footprint of year-round systems. Any such system must be compliant, independently reviewable, non-harmful, dignity-preserving, and operationally legible.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ## Cultural Beacon and Civic Demonstration (Nonpartisan intent)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intended to be more than a sanctuary and more than a destination. It is intended to be a cultural beacon: a lived demonstration that a system can produce trust, safety, and freedom through clear constraints, dignity protections, and routine accountability.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: This aim is explicitly nonpartisan and non-electoral. New Doggerland does not exist to advocate for political parties, candidates, or ideology. It exists to model civic competence: how people can share space, resolve uncertainty, and make decisions transparently without informal power, retaliation, or extraction.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: In this sense, New Doggerland is intended to be an example of ``how politics can work'' in the most basic meaning of the word: how a community governs itself. The public interface (education, visible partnerships, and dignity-preserving access) exists in part to make these principles legible to ordinary visitors, not only to auditors.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The Founder is intentionally designing New Doggerland so that it can function ethically as if the Founder is absent, including absence due to retirement, incapacity, death, conflict, or ordinary turnover.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The governance and operational stack is intended to:

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• prevent informal authority from substituting for rules,
• preserve mission lock across leadership transitions,
• make major decisions reconstructable through logs and recorded pathways,
• and resist capture by bad-faith actors or drift under financial pressure.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: The Founder role is architecture and long-horizon coherence, not control. If the institution cannot function ethically without founder presence, it is considered structurally incomplete.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: ## Audit-Native Assumption (Near-Zero Verification Costs, Dignity Preserved)

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is built with the expectation that audit, monitoring, and verification costs are declining. The institution is intended to make verification easy without creating coercive surveillance.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• decisions should be legible after the fact through logs and recorded pathways,
• accountability should be routine rather than punitive,
• and trust should not depend on any single person.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Any use of monitoring technology is intended to be minimal, purpose-limited to safety and integrity, protected against misuse, and never used for commercial profiling, advertising, coercion, or punishment.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: New Doggerland is intended to proceed through gated phases, advancing only when welfare, dignity, maintenance capacity, safety performance, and logging integrity remain stable.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• establish care routines and safety procedures,
• establish logging discipline and review habits,
• prove basic operability without informal authority.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• stabilize sanctuary/rescue/adoption operations within proven carrying capacity,
• demonstrate that logs and reviews remain current under load,
• establish consistent veterinary and grooming support.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• introduce limited public access and education in reversible, bounded forms,
• validate safety and dignity outcomes without welfare degradation,
• refine procedures so autonomy remains safe.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• expand infrastructure only when maintenance capacity is demonstrated,
• build staffing layers that prevent single points of failure,
• mature audit readiness and external review routines.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• operate as a durable institution with stable welfare outputs and stable dignity protections,
• evolve slowly without drift,
• preserve governance legibility across generations.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: Progression is intended to be capacity-driven, not ambition-driven.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text:
• a growth-first platform or scale-at-all-costs organization,
• a founder-controlled institution,
• an entertainment venue that compromises welfare or dignity,
• a vehicle for private extraction, prestige, or informal entitlements,
• a system where emergency logic becomes a substitute for governance,
• a surveillance-driven environment that substitutes monitoring for design, competence, and trust.

entries.label: Founder Vision
entries.text: This document may be revised for clarity and fidelity to the Founder’s intent, but it must remain strictly subordinate and derived. Any revision that could be interpreted as creating new obligations, permissions, thresholds, or authority must be rejected.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
Status: Non-binding explanatory companion \\
Authority: Subordinate to ``New Doggerland - Consolidated Governance Document v0.6.0'' \\
Purpose: Explain intentions and mechanisms without creating new obligations

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: This document is a readable explanation of how the Consolidated Governance Document is designed to function in practice. It is written to help:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• board members,
• staff,
• partner organizations,
• donors,
• auditors, and
• future stewards

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• a source of authority,
• policy,
• an operational manual,
• a substitute for the Consolidated Governance Document,
• or a mechanism to reinterpret rules.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: If there is any difference between this companion and the Consolidated Governance Document, the Consolidated Governance Document controls.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: This companion is a reader’s guide. It explains intent, mechanism, and the mental model of the governance system. It is not a source of new obligations.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• Design intent in one paragraph
• The core logic of the system
• What to do when confused (below)

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• Staff / contributors: Read for boundaries and escalation routes. Focus on constraints, discretion limits, and how to route uncertainty.
• Stewards / governance roles: Read for decision-shaping principles, interpretation rules, and what makes a decision legitimate.
• Partners / funders / external reviewers: Read for capture-resistance, mission lock, and how conflicts are contained and made reviewable.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• Mission lock first: the organization has a constrained purpose-space; some actions are simply not allowed.
• Welfare and dignity constraints: dog welfare and human dignity bound what can be justified, even under pressure.
• Lowest competent level: decisions should be made as close to the work as competence and risk allow.
• Bounded discretion: discretion exists, but must be explainable and routed through reviewable pathways.
• Recorded pathways: when stakes are material, decision logic must be legible after the fact.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: When a clause feels unclear, do exactly this, in order:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• Identify whether the question is about purpose, authority, process, or interpretation.
• Prefer the most constraint-preserving interpretation (the one least likely to expand power or undermine welfare or dignity).
• Route the uncertainty through the smallest legitimate escalation path, and record the rationale if it affects procedure.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: If you need a single test: Could a good-faith reviewer understand why this choice was made, and see that it remained inside the mission lock?

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: New Doggerland’s governance is designed to resist capture, prevent private extraction, and preserve mission integrity over multiple generations. The system assumes that failure modes will occur, good-faith mistakes, ambiguous circumstances, missing information, emergencies, and occasional bad-faith actors, and it therefore encodes safeguards that force decisions into transparent, reviewable pathways with explicit limits on authority.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: For the intended end state and staged pathway, see Founder Vision. It confers no authority.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: The governance framework begins by defining the organization’s allowed purpose-space. It does this by establishing that:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• the organization exists solely for its stated charitable, welfare, and stewardship purposes, and
• no activity may undermine dog welfare, human dignity, or long-term stewardship.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: Every section of the Consolidated Governance Document declares a mutability class. Where multiple mutability declarations apply, the most specific declaration governs. This means that subsection-level mutability overrides section-level mutability.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: Unchangeable provisions are intended to remain fixed. Revisable provisions may change only through the specified governance process. Adaptive provisions may evolve within explicitly defined bounds.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: The governance system explicitly allows for a bounded Foundational Phase during which certain governance mechanisms or operational systems may not yet be fully instantiated. This flexibility is:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• temporary,
• explicitly recorded,
• non-precedential, and
• subject to automatic expiration.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: This mechanism exists to permit safe early operation without weakening mission lock or authority constraints.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: ### Hierarchy determines authority, not interpretation

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: The hierarchy section establishes that different document layers exist, but clarifies a critical point:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• Hierarchy governs authority.
• Interpretation still requires good faith and narrow reading.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: ### ``Material Action'' is the system’s primary trigger concept

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: A large portion of the document exists to ensure that important actions cannot be performed casually.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: ### Recorded Decision Pathways are the audit spine

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: A Recorded Decision Pathway is the minimum complete record showing:

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• what was decided,
• who authorized it,
• when it happened,
• what it affects, and
• what authority was relied upon.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: ### Interpretation notes exist, but are deliberately defanged

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: Interpretation notes are permitted at the lowest competent level only for non-material actions, and only where no conflict exists.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: The Founder is defined as a continuity and coherence role. The design deliberately forbids the Founder from having voting power, veto power, unilateral authority, ownership interest, or a governance seat by default.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: The residence provisions are designed as continuity and dignity protections, not as transferable benefits.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text:
• non-owning residency,
• non-transferability,
• explicit protection against displacement,
• termination upon abuse, and
• constraints to preserve safety and operations.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: Residency protections exist for the Founder, surviving spouse, and certain narrowly defined service-based roles. Where specified in the Consolidated Governance Document, these protections are lifetime, dignity-preserving, and non-extractive, and never create ownership, inheritance, income rights, or governance authority.

entries.label: Governance Companion
entries.text: This companion document may be updated for clarity and readability, but must remain strictly derived from the Consolidated Governance Document. Any update that could be interpreted as creating new obligations must be rejected.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: This manual is written for execution. It is organized so you can:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• find the relevant procedure quickly,
• understand what must be done vs.\ what may be adapted, and
• know when to escalate.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• First pass (15--20 minutes): skim section headings to learn where things live.
• Second pass (as-needed): use the section that matches the task you are doing; do not read linearly unless onboarding.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• the decision is materially irreversible,
• the decision materially affects dog welfare, human dignity, or long-horizon stewardship,
• the decision creates a precedent others will rely on,
• you cannot explain the choice in a way that would satisfy a good-faith reviewer.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: When in doubt: choose the most welfare-preserving and least power-expanding option, then request review.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF an operational instruction conflicts with the Constitution, THEN the instruction is void and must not be followed.
• IF an operational instruction conflicts with law, THEN the instruction must be escalated to Governing Body for correction.
• IF an operational gap is discovered, THEN staff must halt discretionary action and escalate for guidance, EXCEPT THAT: IF the affected action is routine, reversible, and within the actor’s role scope, THEN the actor may implement a temporary bounded control ONLY IF the control creates no lasting obligation, transfers or risks no assets, is reversible without Governing Body approval, is logged at time of action with a GAP-BRIDGE reason code and an explicit expiration time not exceeding 72 hours, AND the Governing Body is notified for review as soon as feasible.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • For purposes of this section, an operational gap exists only when no existing instruction, role norm, or prior recorded decision pathway reasonably applies to the action as executed.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • This gap-bridge cannot be used to authorize contracts, spending, partner commitments, staff discipline, access revocation, policy changes, or any action that would be a Material Action under the Constitution as defined in Governance Schedule A (10.10).

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF a GAP-BRIDGE is used for the same operational gap or a substantially similar action more than once within any rolling 30-day period, THEN the Governing Body must place the gap on the next regular meeting agenda for corrective instruction, AND further GAP-BRIDGE use for that gap is prohibited unless Governing Body expressly authorizes continuation in writing.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF an operational gap is discovered AND stopping work would cause imminent harm to dog welfare or human dignity,
THEN invoke Emergency Invocation (OM-11) only to implement the minimum temporary control needed to prevent that harm,
AND record (1) the gap, (2) the harm risk, (3) the temporary control, (4) who authorized it, and (5) an expiration time,
AND notify Governing Body for review as soon as feasible,
ELSE halt the affected action until Governing Body issues guidance.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • OM-0 GAP-BRIDGE and OM-1 PROVISIONAL-AUTHORITY are two labels for the same temporary control class: PROVISIONAL CONTROL. IF either pathway is invoked, THEN all prohibitions, logging requirements, expiration limits, and non-precedent rules from BOTH sections apply cumulatively, and the strictest constraint controls.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF a decision materially affects welfare, safety, dignity, assets, or land, THEN documented approval by the Governing Body is required.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • Material Action thresholds and escalation triggers are defined exclusively in Governance Schedule A (10.10).

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF a decision is routine and reversible, THEN designated staff may act within their role scope.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF authority is unclear, THEN the decision must not proceed until clarified, EXCEPT THAT: IF the decision is routine, reversible, and within the actor’s role scope, THEN the actor may proceed provisionally ONLY IF the actor creates a log stub at time of action with a PROVISIONAL-AUTHORITY reason code, states the narrow intended scope, and sets an expiration time not exceeding 72 hours; AND IF any reasonable disagreement arises that the action is materially affecting OR if the action proves not reversible without further authorization, THEN the provisional action must stop and be escalated immediately for Governing Body review; AND this provisional pathway cannot be used to create obligations, commit funds, discipline staff, revoke access, or establish precedent.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF PROVISIONAL-AUTHORITY is invoked for the same decision category more than once within any rolling 30-day period, THEN the actor must escalate for Governing Body clarification before any further provisional action in that category.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • For purposes of this section, a decision category is defined by the nature of the authority ambiguity and the class of impact, not by superficial differences in fact pattern or execution context.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • Authority is not unclear solely because an action has not been previously executed, documented, or reviewed, provided it is routine, reversible, and within established role scope.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF a proposed action prioritizes short-term gain over long-term stewardship, THEN the action must not proceed.
• IF a proposal risks degradation of welfare, safety, or dignity, THEN it must be rejected or redesigned.
• IF maintenance capacity is insufficient, THEN expansion or acquisition must pause.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF an asset cannot be reasonably maintained, THEN it must not be acquired or must be retired.
• IF an asset degrades welfare or safety, THEN it must be repaired, replaced, or removed.
• IF durable and repairable options exist at reasonable cost, THEN disposable options must not be selected.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF a partner relationship involves extraction, exploitation, or misalignment, THEN it must not be entered.
• IF alignment is uncertain, THEN provisional engagement requires Governing Body review.
• IF a partner violates ND constraints, THEN the relationship must be suspended pending review.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF staff act in good faith and make errors, THEN correction and support are required, not punishment.
• IF staff act in bad faith, conceal harm, or retaliate, THEN disciplinary action is mandatory.
• IF dignity is compromised, THEN operations must stop until the issue is addressed.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF a hazard is identified, THEN it must be marked, logged, and communicated.
• IF a hazard poses immediate risk, THEN access must be restricted.
• IF conditions return to a safe state, THEN restrictions may be lifted.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF an override is required to prevent immediate harm, THEN it must be documented with reason, scope, and duration.
• IF an override is undocumented, THEN it is invalid.
• IF an override exceeds necessity, THEN it must be reversed.
• IF an override occurs, THEN it must be classified under the Constitution’s Classification, Arbitration, and Accountability provisions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF a material action occurs, THEN it must be logged.
• IF an action cannot be logged in the primary system, THEN it must not occur, EXCEPT THAT: IF the action is routine, reversible, and within role scope, THEN the action may proceed ONLY IF the actor creates an offline log stub at time of action containing timestamp, actor, scope, reason code, and invocation basis, and the stub is stored in a tamper-evident manner designated by Governance Schedule D (10.40).

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF an offline stub is used, THEN the actor must enter the stub into the primary system within 72 hours of restored logging capability, as required by Governance Schedule D (10.40).

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: • IF offline stub usage recurs beyond defined norms OR any required stub field is missing, THEN automatic review is triggered under OM-11 or the Constitution’s Classification, Arbitration, and Accountability provisions as applicable.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF records are incomplete, THEN remediation is required.
• IF an emergency requires immediate action, THEN action may proceed without prior logging solely to prevent imminent harm.
• IF logging is delayed beyond the emergency window, THEN the action must undergo classification review under OM-11.
• Logging is satisfied at time of action by creation of a minimal log stub containing timestamp, actor, scope, reason code, and invocation basis. Full narrative logging may be completed later as permitted elsewhere in this Manual.
• A valid emergency log stub must reference a pre-defined emergency category code and affected registry objects. Free-text-only stubs are invalid.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF failure occurs without bad faith, THEN transparency and correction are required.
• IF failure involves concealment or intent to harm, THEN escalation is mandatory.
• IF learning can prevent recurrence, THEN procedures must be updated.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• IF an operational rule causes harm or friction, THEN it must be reviewed.
• IF improvements are identified, THEN revisions may be proposed.
• IF revisions conflict with the Constitution, THEN they must not be adopted.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF immediate action is required and normal authorization is infeasible, THEN staff may act narrowly to prevent harm.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF emergency action occurs, THEN the action must be logged within the emergency window or undergo classification review under the Constitution’s Classification, Arbitration, and Accountability provisions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
Emergency authority may only affect assets, systems, or persons explicitly listed in the Emergency Scope Registry as defined in the Constitution.
 Actions outside the registry are void.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Each emergency invocation authorizes either (A) one discrete action, OR (B) one tightly-related response bundle consisting only of actions necessary to control a single emergency condition.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Emergency invocation does not establish precedent and must not be cited as authorization for future actions outside the specific emergency condition documented.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF a response bundle is used, THEN the actor must (1) list each bundled action in the emergency log stub, (2) state the single emergency condition being controlled, (3) state the stop condition, and (4) set an expiration time not exceeding 4 hours.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF the emergency condition persists beyond the expiration time OR the scope expands to a different emergency condition, THEN a new emergency invocation and new log stub are required.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: A response bundle must not include contracts, partner commitments, staff discipline, access revocation, policy changes, or any action that is irreversible without Governing Body approval.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• it directly prevents imminent harm
• no less invasive alternative is available
• duration is limited
• no unrelated risks are introduced
• Emergency authority must not be used for actions that are irreversible without Governing Body approval.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF any criterion is not met, THEN classification review is mandatory.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF emergency authority is invoked more than once by the same individual within a rolling 90-day window, THEN an automatic pattern review must occur.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an individual invokes emergency authority, THEN any additional invocation by that individual within the next 24 hours automatically triggers a mandatory pattern review flag, but does not prohibit invocation when needed to prevent imminent harm.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Pattern review must not presume misconduct and must default to Mistake classification unless evidence supports Violation or Abuse under the Constitution’s Classification, Arbitration, and Accountability provisions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF emergency authority is invoked, THEN the system must:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Timestamp the action
• Flag the actor’s account
• Schedule mandatory log entry within 72 hours
• Notify Governing Body and Audit roles

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
Emergency invocations must be logged and made available for external arbiter or audit observer review.
Automatic notification to an external arbiter or audit observer is required only if one or more of the following conditions are met:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• the emergency action is not fully reversed within its declared expiration window
• the emergency action materially affects a person, asset, or domain beyond the immediate emergency condition
• the same actor invokes emergency authority more than once within a rolling 90-day window
• any required log element is missing, inconsistent, or delayed beyond permitted limits

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• All emergency invocations automatically start a review clock.
• IF the actor is incapacitated, displaced, detained, or under coercion, THEN the logging deadline is tolled until the incapacity ends.
• IF incapacity tolling is invoked, THEN the actor must complete logging within 72 hours of restored capacity.
• IF incapacity tolling exceeds 14 days, THEN automatic Classification Panel review is triggered.
• IF incapacity tolling is claimed without reasonable basis or supporting evidence, THEN the action escalates directly to Violation review.
IF a Classification Panel review is triggered, THEN the invoking actor’s emergency authority is automatically suspended until review closure.
• Expiration of the review clock without documented closure requires automatic human review by the Classification Panel or its delegate.
• No emergency action may bypass quorum, term-validity, or classification safeguards required by the Constitution.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF emergency authority is invoked beyond peer norms within a rolling period, THEN the system must generate a comparative analytics report and initiate mandatory Classification Panel review.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF review volume exceeds capacity thresholds, THEN the Classification Panel must prioritize cases by demonstrated or potential harm. Deferred cases remain logged and reviewable.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: ## OM-A. Pre-Registration Operating Kernel (Day-1)

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
Status: Binding during pre-registration phase only \\
Authority: Subordinate to the Constitution and Consolidated Governance Document \\
Expiration: This section expires automatically upon formal organizational registration or activation of a Governing Body, whichever occurs first.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: This section defines a temporary execution kernel applicable only during the pre-registration phase.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: This section creates no governance authority, confers no voting power, and does not modify any role defined in higher-order documents.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF the Founder is acting in an operational capacity, THEN the Founder may execute only routine, reversible, role-scoped actions necessary for care, safety, or maintenance.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF Emergency Authority is invoked, THEN it must comply fully with the Emergency Invocation and Emergency Scope Registry provisions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an action would create an obligation, contract, disciplinary effect, exclusion, or irreversible commitment, THEN the action must not be taken.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF any other person is present in a helper, volunteer, or contractor capacity, THEN that person may act only under explicit role-scoped instruction or Emergency Authority.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF authority is unclear, THEN the action must halt unless it is routine, reversible, and logged as provisional under GAP-BRIDGE rules.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF any of the following occur, THEN the action must be logged at the time of action or immediately upon stabilization:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Emergency Authority invocation
• Provisional or GAP-BRIDGE control use
• Any action affecting dog welfare
• Any action affecting human dignity
• Any access restriction
• Any safety condition
• Any asset use beyond trivial consumption

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Minimum required log fields during pre-registration:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Timestamp
• Actor
• Bounded factual description
• Reason code (EMERGENCY / PROVISIONAL / ROUTINE)
• Explicit expiration, if applicable

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF immediate logging is not possible due to active harm prevention, THEN logging must occur as soon as the condition stabilizes and must state the delay reason.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Logs must be reviewed periodically to identify cumulative effects that may not be evident from individual actions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an action is not reversible, THEN it must be escalated.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an action creates precedent, THEN it must be escalated.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an action affects housing, access, discipline, or exclusion, THEN it must be escalated.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF the actor cannot explain the action to a neutral reviewer without defensiveness, THEN the action must be escalated.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF no escalation body exists, THEN the actor must halt unless imminent harm exists, in which case the GAP-BRIDGE pathway must be used with explicit expiration and notification.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: The following actions are prohibited at all times, including during emergencies:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Informal bans, evictions, or access revocations are prohibited.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Compensation-by-sacrifice expectations are prohibited.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF an action is procedurally prohibited, THEN it must not be taken regardless of perceived moral justification.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF Emergency Authority is invoked, THEN actions must be narrowly scoped to a single harm condition.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF four hours elapse after Emergency Authority invocation, THEN either the emergency must be declared resolved or the matter must transition to governance-level handling.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Emergency Authority must not be used to normalize unresolved conditions.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: ## OM-B. Pre-Registration Pilot Guidance (First 30 Days)

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
Status: Non-binding execution guidance \\
Authority: Subordinate to Operational Manual \\
Function: Planning and classification aid only

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Recognized roles during pre-registration are limited to:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Founder acting as operational staff
• Helper or volunteer with no independent discretion
• Dog groomer (if facilities are present)
• External advisors with no authority

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: The following table is a classification aid only. It does not grant permission.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
Temporary dog intake & Yes (bounded) & Explicit duration cap required \\
Emergency veterinary care & Yes & Emergency scope only \\
Food sourcing & Yes & No contracts permitted \\
Small equipment purchase & Yes & Subject to spending cap defined in Governance Schedule A (10.10) \\
Visitor presence & No & Requires explicit rule \\
Overnight guest & No & Default deny \\
Dog isolation & Yes & Must be logged \\
Access restriction & Emergency only & Never informal \\
Housing use & No & Governance-level \\
Media contact & No & Must not improvise \\

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF a decision is not explicitly classified, THEN the decision must not be executed except under Emergency Invocation.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF any of the following conditions occur, THEN expansion actions must pause immediately:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Any dog lacks daily care coverage
• Maintenance backlog exceeds seven days
• Logging falls behind more than seventy-two hours
• Emergency Authority is invoked twice within thirty days

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: During pre-registration, the following logging mechanism is permitted:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• One bound logbook with numbered pages
• One ink color only
• No page removal
• Index maintained at front

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: This allowance expires upon digital system activation.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF the bound-logbook mechanism remains the sole logging system beyond ninety (90) days of operation, THEN the acting operator must document the reason for delay and place digital logging transition on the next governance or review agenda.

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: IF operating during pre-registration, THEN once per week the acting operator must:

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text:
• Review all logs
• Flag any discomfort or ambiguity
• Record one sentence addressing potential external review concern

entries.label: Operational Manual
entries.text: Failure to perform weekly review constitutes operational degradation.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
Status: Non-binding explanatory companion \\
Authority: Subordinate to ``New Doggerland - Operational Manual v0.6.0'' and, above it, to ``New Doggerland - Consolidated Governance Document v0.6.0'' \\
Purpose: Explain intentions and mechanisms without creating new obligations

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This companion is here to make the operational manual easier to live with:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• it explains why procedures exist,
• it clarifies how to apply judgment without drifting out of bounds,
• it gives a shared language for tradeoffs, exceptions, and review.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• this section,
• the sections that define discretion limits and escalation,
• only then the manual sections you will actively use in your role.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This companion does not override the operational manual or the consolidated governance document. Where there is any conflict, the higher-authority document controls.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This document is a readable explanation of how the Operational Manual is designed to function in practice. It is written to help:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• staff,
• supervisors,
• partner organizations,
• auditors, and
• future stewards

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: understand the operational logic quickly and accurately.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• a source of authority,
• policy,
• a substitute for the Operational Manual,
• a mechanism to reinterpret rules, or
• a permission to deviate from the Operational Manual.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: If there is any difference between this companion and the Operational Manual, the Operational Manual controls. If there is any difference between the Operational Manual and the Consolidated Governance Document, the Consolidated Governance Document controls.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The Operational Manual exists to convert New Doggerland’s governance constraints into executable operational behavior. It assumes that front-line work encounters ambiguity, missing instructions, system outages, urgent conditions, and human error. It therefore encodes narrow default rules, escalation triggers, and logging requirements so that routine work can continue safely, while non-routine or materially affecting actions are forced into attributable, reviewable pathways.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The Operational Manual is written as IF / THEN logic because staff must be able to execute rules under stress without interpretive debate. The goal is mechanical compliance: identify the trigger, perform the required action, and log what the rule requires.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: ### The Manual is subordinate and cannot create new authority

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The Manual cannot create new powers, override prohibitions, or expand emergency authority beyond what the Governance Document permits. Where a rule requires escalation, the escalation requirement exists specifically to prevent staff from being placed in the role of governance.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• If an operational instruction conflicts with the Constitution, it is void.
• If an operational instruction conflicts with law, it must be escalated for correction.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This prevents a common failure mode where staff follow an internal checklist that is wrong but ``in writing.''

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: ### Operational gaps and the GAP-BRIDGE / PROVISIONAL CONTROL mechanism

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-0 defines an operational gap narrowly: it exists only when no existing instruction, role norm, or prior recorded decision pathway reasonably applies to the action as executed.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: When a gap exists, the default is to halt discretionary action and escalate for guidance. The only exception is the GAP-BRIDGE pathway, which is a tightly constrained temporary control permitted only when the action is routine, reversible, within role scope, creates no lasting obligation, risks no assets, and is logged with a reason code and short expiration.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Allow limited continuity for small reversible actions.
• Prevent the gap mechanism from becoming a shadow authority channel.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-0 also forces corrective governance action when a repeated gap appears. If the same gap is bridged more than once in a rolling 30-day period, governance must address it and further gap-bridge use is prohibited absent written continuation.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: ### Imminent harm exception routes to Emergency Invocation

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: If an operational gap exists and stopping work would cause imminent harm to dog welfare or human dignity, OM-0 routes the actor to Emergency Invocation (OM-11) with a minimum-control requirement, explicit record fields, and a short expiration.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This is intended to ensure that harm-prevention is possible without turning ``gaps'' into permissions.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: ### GAP-BRIDGE and PROVISIONAL-AUTHORITY are unified

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-0 explicitly states that OM-0 GAP-BRIDGE and OM-1 PROVISIONAL-AUTHORITY are two labels for the same temporary control class (PROVISIONAL CONTROL) and that the strictest constraints apply cumulatively.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Materially affecting decisions require documented approval by the governing authority.
• Routine and reversible decisions may be executed within role scope.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-1 then provides a narrow provisional pathway when authority is unclear. The mechanism requires contemporaneous logging, narrow scope, short expiration, and immediate escalation if reversibility fails or reasonable disagreement arises about materiality. It also prohibits use for obligations, funds, discipline, access revocation, or precedent.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-1 further defines a ``decision category'' as the nature of the authority ambiguity and class of impact, preventing superficial variations from being used to evade the 30-day repetition trigger.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-2 turns stewardship principles into stop rules:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Short-term gain cannot override long-term stewardship.
• Proposals that risk welfare, safety, or dignity must be rejected or redesigned.
• Expansion pauses when maintenance capacity is insufficient.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This exists to prevent growth from outpacing the organization’s ability to maintain humane, safe operations.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-3 imposes acquisition and maintenance discipline:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Do not acquire what cannot be maintained.
• Repair, replace, or remove assets that degrade welfare or safety.
• Prefer durable and repairable options over disposable ones when reasonable.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The design intent is ``nonprofits can’t afford to buy cheap things'' translated into operational stop conditions.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-4 is designed to prevent extraction and misalignment entering through partnerships:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Do not enter exploitative or misaligned relationships.
• If alignment is uncertain, provisional engagement requires governance review.
• If a partner violates ND constraints, suspend pending review.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This prevents partners from becoming a backdoor governance channel.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Good-faith errors require correction and support, not punishment.
• Bad faith, concealment, harm, or retaliation requires mandatory discipline.
• If dignity is compromised, operations stop until addressed.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The intent is consistent with the Governance Document’s classification logic and anti-retaliation posture.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Identify, mark, log, and communicate hazards.
• Restrict access when hazards pose immediate risk.
• Lift restrictions when conditions return to a safe state.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This provides consistent field behavior that can be audited.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-7 treats overrides as exceptional and reviewable:

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Overrides are permitted only to prevent immediate harm and must be documented with reason, scope, and duration.
• Undocumented overrides are invalid.
• Excessive overrides must be reversed.
• Overrides must be classified under the Governance Document’s classification provisions.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This exists to prevent ``temporary'' exceptions from silently becoming permanent.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Material actions must be logged.
• If primary logging is unavailable, actions generally must not occur.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: The exception allows routine, reversible, role-scoped actions to proceed with an offline stub containing required fields, stored tamper-evidently, and entered into the primary system within 72 hours of restored capability.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• preserve continuity for small safe actions during outages,
• keep the audit spine intact,
• force review when offline logging deviates from norms or is incomplete.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-8 also defines minimum stub content and requires emergency stubs to reference pre-defined emergency category codes and registry objects, rejecting free-text-only stubs.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Good-faith failure requires transparency and correction.
• Concealment or intent to harm requires mandatory escalation.
• Procedures must update when learning can prevent recurrence.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text:
• Harm or friction triggers review.
• Improvements may be proposed.
• Conflicts with the Constitution bar adoption.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-11 defines emergency authority as narrow action to prevent harm when normal authorization is infeasible, within the Emergency Scope Registry, and with explicit non-precedent constraints. It distinguishes between one discrete action and one tightly-related response bundle, with listing requirements, stop conditions, and short expirations.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: It explicitly excludes contracts, partner commitments, discipline, access revocation, policy changes, and irreversible actions without Governing Body approval.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-11 imposes a proportionality test to ensure emergency actions remain narrowly scoped and require classification review if criteria are not met.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: ### Rolling invocation triggers and pattern review

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-11 triggers automatic review when the same individual invokes emergency authority more than once in a rolling window and flags repeat invocations within 24 hours. Pattern review does not presume misconduct and defaults to Mistake unless evidence supports Violation or Abuse under the Governance Document.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-11 specifies system behaviors (timestamping, flagging, scheduling mandatory log entry, notifications) and defines when external arbiter or audit observer notification is required based on reversibility, scope expansion, repeat invocation, or logging defects.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: It also defines tolling rules for incapacity and escalation triggers if tolling is abused or exceeds limits, including automatic emergency authority suspension pending review when a Classification Panel review is triggered.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: OM-11 includes comparative analytics reporting for outlier emergency use and a triage rule when review volume exceeds capacity, prioritizing by harm while keeping deferred cases logged and reviewable.

entries.label: Operational Manual Companion
entries.text: This companion document may be updated for clarity and readability, but must remain strictly derived from the Operational Manual. Any update that could be interpreted as creating new obligations must be rejected.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
Status: Non-binding evaluative procedure \\
Authority: Subordinate to New Doggerland -- Consolidated Governance Document v0.6.0 \\
Purpose: Assess eligibility and screen disqualifications for prospective Governing Body members in a manner consistent with the Constitution.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: This document derives authority solely from the Consolidated Governance Document. It does not grant authority, create obligations, modify eligibility thresholds, or override any constitutional provision.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Failure to follow this process does not validate an ineligible appointment and may constitute a governance process failure.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• evaluates eligibility under the Constitution,
• documents evidence relied upon,
• does not substitute for removal, classification, or enforcement procedures,
• does not limit Governing Body discretion within constitutional bounds.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: This process must not be treated as an independent source of authority.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Vetting must proceed in the order below. Failure at any stage terminates the process.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: ### Stage 1 -- Independence and Disclosure Screening

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: The candidate must provide written disclosure confirming:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• ability to act independently,
• absence of prohibited relationships,
• disclosure of all Material Financial Interests,
• acknowledgment of a continuing disclosure obligation.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
IF any disqualifying relationship or undisclosed conflict exists, THEN terminate vetting. \\
ELSE proceed to Stage 2.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: The candidate must demonstrate a sustained, good-faith commitment to one or more of the following:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• animal welfare,
• human welfare,
• responsible animal stewardship.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Evaluation is based on documented conduct, not self-asserted values or affinity.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Acceptable evidence may include, without limitation:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• long-term primary dog ownership or caregiving history,
• foster, rescue, or shelter involvement,
• veterinary, behavioral, training, or welfare-adjacent professional work,
• governance, financial, or operational support of welfare organizations,
• sustained volunteer or advocacy work involving animals or vulnerable people,
• other documented activities demonstrating responsibility, restraint, and care.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
IF evidence demonstrates sustained engagement, THEN proceed. \\
IF evidence is episodic, superficial, or purely declarative, THEN terminate vetting.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: The candidate must attest, and the organization must reasonably confirm, that none of the following apply:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• conviction for animal cruelty, animal abuse, or animal neglect,
• substantiated judicial or regulatory finding for animal cruelty, abuse, or neglect,
• conviction or substantiated finding for cruelty toward humans.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Where uncertainty exists, classification defaults to disqualification until resolved.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Reasonable confirmation does not require exhaustive investigation and may rely on good-faith attestations, public records, and information reasonably available at the time.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
IF any disqualifying record exists, THEN terminate vetting. \\
ELSE proceed to Stage 4.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: ### Stage 4 -- Continuing-Condition Acknowledgment

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• Governing Body membership is conditional on continued compliance with eligibility and disqualification requirements,
• discovery of disqualifying conduct triggers mandatory review and removal,
• omission or concealment of relevant information may itself constitute cause for removal.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: For each vetted candidate, the following must be retained in governance records:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• written disclosure statement,
• welfare-commitment evidence summary,
• disqualification attestation,
• names of reviewers,
• date of final eligibility determination.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• rely on subjective affinity or narrative alone,
• impose dog ownership as a requirement,
• evaluate ideological alignment unrelated to welfare,
• apply standards selectively or inconsistently,
• create informal exceptions or waivers.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• does not limit Governing Body removal authority,
• does not preempt Classification Panel review,
• does not shield a member from consequences of later findings.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: Discovery of disqualifying conduct after appointment must be handled under the Governing Body removal provisions and the Classification, Arbitration, and Accountability framework.

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text: This vetting process may be revised to improve clarity or reflect new evidence types, provided that revisions:

entries.label: Board Vetting Process
entries.text:
• remain strictly derivative of the Constitution,
• do not narrow constitutional disqualifications,
• do not add new eligibility constraints,
• do not create discretion beyond evaluation.
